TopicTitle: What would a switch to n-body physics take?

Articles.Content: I know that it would take A LOT of computing power to switch to n-body physics but just how much, and on that, what are the other challenges?![:confused:](//kerbal-forum-uploads.s3.us-west-2.amazonaws.com/emoticons/default_k_huh.gif)
[This has been asked many times before, and discussed to Moho and back.](https://www.google.com/search?q=site%3Aforum.kerbalspaceprogram.com+%22n-body%22)
I think it would be bad for gameplay. orbital decay killing a different mission while you timewarp to jool would suck
N-body physics would be like LS. It would require you to do station keeping on almost all vessels, which would be come a massive pain very quick.

"Station keeping" could easily be abstracted away, handled automatically in return for a slow drain of fuel. It would give satellites and similar things finite lifespans and encourage the player to make tradeoffs - a light satellite with little fuel that's cheap to launch but will soon lose stationkeeping, or a heavier satellite with extra fuel that's more expensive to launch but will maintain its desired orbit for longer.

Squad has said that they have no desire to try to make a transition to N-body. In fact, it's on the [What Not to Suggest List](https://forum.kerbalspaceprogram.com/threads/36863-What-not-to-suggest). Assuming that you just want to discuss it as an intellectual problem, though, this thread has been moved to the off-topic lounge. Keep in mind, though, that trying to persuade Squad to make the change will get the thread closed.

A far as I understand, in patched conics, timewarp has a pretty little effect on accuracy. You can skip a collision at a high timewarp value, but the coordinates are functions of orbital parameters and time only and can be evaluated accurately regardless of timewarp.

In *n*-body physics, the coordinates of bodies depend on their previous values. During timewarp, you have to increase the distance between time samples so the accuracy degrades.

Hi.

N-body physics probably isn't going to make it into the stock game. The [Principia](https://forum.kerbalspaceprogram.com/threads/68502) mod does implement N-body physics over KSP's stock orbital mechanics. As a WIP mod, it comes with no guarantees that it will not crash, corrupt saves or do various other interesting things. However, if you want wobbly orbits, L-points and moons getting flung out of the Jool system and into deep space, that's the one to try.

You can get the mod by joining the #principia channel on Espernet and asking. Be aware that the ops there may not always be awake, so hang around until you get an answer.
